creator: sfhowes

content: Thanks. I've tried that a number of times today and in the past but it does not bring back the choice banner and there seems to be no way to do that. sometimes the remote content may be from other associated domains and so whitelisting the email source does not solve the problem. It is very puzzling and annoying that there is no way to change one's mind after clicking the wrong choice by mistake.
creator: allendick

content: In cases where remote content in a single message is loaded from several sources (associated domains), merely whitelisting the sender might not be sufficient. It's probably easier to just delete all entries from Exceptions and force the Options banner to appear for all new messages. Short of trying to figure out which domains to block or unblock, I don't know of any other way to reset.

content: My first thought is to set up a filter for the project, assuming there is some element within each message that would identify it. Maybe more information on how the emails for a project are identified, or is this a manual step that you do?
creator: davidsk

content:
Hi David,

Thanks for your reply.

Messages come in to Outlook 2003 and when I have dealt with that particular message I manually move it to a project directory in Outlook 2003, together with any message I have sent. This directory is specific to one project and all emails pertaining to that project sit there. Once that project is complete and email correspondence ceases, then using MessageSave, I manually select that project directory and save all the emails to the main project directory on C:.

When I send an email I always preface the subject area with the project number, however, my correspondents (client, contractor, local authority, suppliers etc.) often put their own "subject" so identification for me is a manual process.
creator: graham3443
